title: The Passover Instituted
shortSummary: Exodus 12 details the institution of the Passover, a pivotal event marking God's deliverance of Israel from Egyptian bondage. It outlines the instructions for the Passover lamb, the feast of unleavened bread, and God's judgment on Egypt, culminating in Israel's departure from slavery.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: God's appointed leader who communicates God's commands to Israel and leads them out of Egypt.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Moses' brother and spokesman who assists in delivering God's instructions to the people.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The Egyptian ruler who experiences the final plague and commands Israel to leave Egypt.

definitions.definition: The annual Jewish feast commemorating God's deliverance of Israel from the final plague in Egypt by 'passing over' the houses marked with lamb's blood.
Bread made without yeast, eaten during the seven-day feast to symbolize purity and haste in leaving Egypt.
A plant used ceremonially to apply the lamb’s blood to the doorposts, symbolizing cleansing and protection.
The eldest child or animal, significant here as the target of God's judgment on Egypt.

outline.heading: Instructions for the Passover Lamb
outline.description: God commands Israel to select a spotless lamb on the tenth day of the first month, to be sacrificed on the fourteenth day, with its blood marking their doorposts as a sign of protection from the coming judgment.

outline.heading: The Feast of Unleavened Bread and Its Observance
outline.description: God institutes a seven-day feast of unleavened bread to be observed forever, emphasizing the removal of leaven as a symbol of purity and remembrance of Israel’s swift deliverance.

outline.heading: Implementation of the Passover and God's Judgment
outline.description: Moses instructs the elders to carry out the Passover; at midnight, God strikes down all Egyptian firstborn, prompting Pharaoh to urgently release Israel.

outline.heading: Israel’s Departure and God's Favor
outline.description: Israel departs Egypt hastily, taking unleavened dough and receiving wealth from the Egyptians, demonstrating God's favor and fulfillment of His promises.

outline.heading: The Significance and Perpetuity of the Passover
outline.description: The chapter concludes by emphasizing the historical duration of Israel’s sojourn in Egypt and the establishment of the Passover as a lasting ordinance for all generations.

application: Trust in God's deliverance by remembering His past faithfulness, as Israel did through the Passover.
Obey God's commands precisely, recognizing that His instructions are for our protection and blessing.
Celebrate and teach the significance of Christ as our ultimate Passover Lamb who delivers from sin and death.
Live in readiness and holiness, symbolized by the removal of leaven, reflecting a life set apart for God.

keyVerses.text: And the blood shall be to you for a token upon the houses where ye are: and when I see the blood, I will pass over you, and the plague shall not be upon you to destroy you, when I smite the land of Egypt.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the protective power of the lamb’s blood, foreshadowing Christ’s atoning sacrifice.

keyVerses.text: And this day shall be unto you for a memorial; and ye shall keep it a feast to the LORD throughout your generations; ye shall keep it a feast by an ordinance for ever.
keyVerses.significance: God commands the perpetual observance of the Passover as a lasting testimony of His salvation.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass, that at midnight the LORD smote all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh that sat on his throne unto the firstborn of the captive that was in the dungeon ; and all the firstborn of cattle.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the decisive judgment on Egypt, demonstrating God’s power and justice.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass the selfsame day, that the LORD did bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their armies.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the fulfillment of God’s promise and the beginning of Israel’s journey to freedom.
